awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An in vivo/in silico Approach to Delineate the Effect of Age on Pressure Ulcer Susceptibility
awd_abstract_narration:
Pressure ulcers, or bed sores, are a debilitating condition that affects more than 3 million Americans. Today, it is understood that pressure ulcers follow from continued compression of skin in patients that have lost the ability to reposition themselves and relieve that pressure. For example, patients in wheel chairs or patients that have become bedridden frequently suffer from pressure ulcers. Patients of advanced age are particularly prone to pressure ulcers. While we understand the behavioral factors that may, in part, explain this increased incidence, the age-related anatomical and physiological factors that may contribute to increased risk in patients of advanced age have remained mostly unexplored and unknown. This knowledge is important, as it may provide a pathway to age-specific treatment strategies. This project will use a mouse model of pressure ulcer formation and progression to investigate these age-related anatomical and physiological factors and their contribution to the increased risk of pressure ulcers due to age. Furthermore, the research will integrate these results into a comprehensive computational model that will be a first step toward predicting pressure ulcers. With such a model it will be possible to not only design better support systems -- such as wheelchairs, mattresses, and prostheses -- but also to explore novel diagnostic technologies and therapeutic strategies. This project will integrate a diverse group of undergraduate students into the research, using peer mentoring approaches.  Finally, and most importantly, in order to accelerate the transfer of knowledge from this study to the general public, educational podcasts on pressure ulcers will be designed that will be disseminated by integrating them into successful, long-running podcast series.

The overall goal of this research is to quantify the effect of age on non-behavioral factors of pressure ulcer formation using mice as a biological model system in combination with a novel multi-scale, multi-physics computer model.  This goal is supported by two objectives.  The first will determine the non-behavior factors that increase the risk of pressure ulcer initiation in the elderly.  Using young and old mice, the role of skin compliance in the microvascular collapse and ischemia that occurs prior to pressure ulcer will be investigated.  The second objective is to determine the non-behavioral factors that increase the risk of pressure ulcer progression by looking at three contributory factors: ischemic injury, reperfusion injury, and mechanical injury.  For both objectives, the experimental data will be integrated into a multi-scale, multi-physics model that will then be able to link matrix-cell and cell-cell signalling to pressure ulcer formation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Pressure ulcers, commonly known as bed sores, are a significant healthcare burden that primarily afflicts the elderly, bed-ridden, or wheelchair-ridden individuals. The mechanisms of pressure ulcer initiation are clear: compression of skin and underlying tissues leads to tissue hypoxia (lack of oxygen), which in turn sets forward an inflammation cascade that damages the tissue and creates a wound.  Yet, even though this sequence of events is clear, prevention or early detection of pressure ulcers remain extremely challenging. One of the main reasons for this lack of predictive and therapeutic tools is the complex interplay between biomechanics, mechanobiology, and the effect of individual-specific factors such as age and sex. This project, led by Prof. Adrian Buganza Tepole at Purdue University and Prof. Manuel Rausch at The University of Texas at Austin, helped elucidate the contributions of skin biomechanics to pressure ulcer initiation, particularly the effects of age and sex.

 

The team of investigators developed computational models of the skin with a greater level of detail than had been previously done, incorporating knowledge of the skin microvasculature and other tissue heterogeneities, such as multiple skin layers and the presence of hair follicles. This model sheds light on how tissue compression leads to blood vessel collapse and, thus, hypoxia. Furthermore, the investigators coupled the biomechanics model to a systems biology model of inflammation to understand the formation of pressure ulcer wounds after hypoxia. One of the main outcomes of these detailed computational models was the increased understanding of how patient-specific factors influence the onset of the injury. For example, the investigators showed, quantitatively, how thinner and softer skin increases the risk of ulcer initiation. 

 

To complement the theoretical and computational approaches, the team also performed experiments on mice to characterize in detail the changes in skin biomechanics with age and sex. One of the main outcomes of the experimental studies was the observation that skin collagen and skin thickness decreased with age and that sex had an effect with increasing age. In other words, even though there were little differences between male and female skin for young mice, significant changes were observed in older mice, not just for younger mice but also for male and female mice. The loss of collagen and dermal thickness, seen experimentally, supports the computational analysis that showed how these changes increase the risk of pressure ulcer initiation. Additionally, the team investigated the temporal progression of pressure ulcer formation and healing using biological and mechanical markers. Specifically, the team induced pressure ulcers and evaluated various species of cell types, growth factors, and inflammatory markers and matched those against changes in skin/ulcer thickness, structure, and stiffness. These data, collected across four time points, will inform systems’ biological models of pressure ulcers toward predictive approaches that could be used to improve pressure ulcer prevention and care.

 

Lastly, due to the new developments in machine learning and artificial intelligence, the investigators leveraged the data from these experiments to create new models of the tissue based on machine learning approaches. While traditional modeling tools for skin biomechanics are still useful, the investigators showed that data-driven methods lead to more accurate models. One of the limitations of traditional modeling approaches is the difficulty in capturing the variability in response across the population. The new data-driven methods, in particular generative machine learning models, allowed the researchers to capture not just the mechanical response of individual mice but the distribution of responses across the mouse population. These tools are essential to translate the findings to the clinical setting in the near future because of the inherent variability in skin mechanics across individuals. 

 

The software and codes developed through this research were made available to the community through public Github repositories and the Texas Data Repository. Several graduate and undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds participated in conducting this research. The new scientific knowledge and data was shared to the community through multiple peer-reviewed journal publications. The investigators also recorded a podcast episode for the popular biomechanics podcast BOOM (Biomechanics on our minds). Finally, the investigators developed novel educational tools that have been published and made openly available to others to use freely.

Modified by: Manuel K Rausch
